awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: An Ethnographic Study of Local-level Policy Implementation Diversity
awd_abstract_narration:
The research supported by this award investigates the outcomes of cross-scale interactions in contemporary state societies.  This is an important scientific question because when policy is developed at national and state levels it may be assumed that it will be translated and implemented locally as intended.  However, given the known diversity of the United States, it is likely that this is not always the case. Therefore, it is important to identify the pathways by which policies devolve and how they interact with variability both within and between communities. Findings from this research will be of value not only to social scientists who study the changing nature of complex societies but also to policy makers who must take this complexity into account for their policies and programs to achieve their goals.

The research will be conducted by anthropologists Sarah B. Horton (University of Colorado at Denver) and Whitney L. Duncan (University of Northern Colorado). The researchers have chosen to focus on local perceptions of health care service availability as a case study of policy devolution. They will undertake a comparative, longitudinal investigation of how specific residents in two different sites in Colorado, one urban and one rural, connect with and understand the availability of health care services for chronic diseases. Policies are standard across the state but are mediated by different local institutional, historical, and sociocultural contexts. The goal is to see what difference those contexts make. Working cooperatively with local clinics, they will collect data through interviews and participant observation with local stakeholders, patients, and health care staff. They will also analyze local media accounts and relevant documents. Findings from this research will be valuable for policy makers, service providers, and service users. The research will also enrich social scientific understanding of the complex functioning of the contemporary state and the different ways in which citizenship is made concrete at the local level.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to study the ways that local-level and state policies shape the willingness of Latino immigrants to utilize health care despite a federal policy climate some have characterized as “decidedly hostile.” To that end, we examined how localities—which differ by policy, health care institutions, and history and duration of immigrant settlement-- interact with broader policies and definitions of “health citizenship” to facilitate immigrants’ health care access, community incorporation, and sense of inclusion in the nation. The co-PIs thus conducted a comparative, longitudinal investigation of Latino immigrants’ perceptions of their ”deservingness” of health care in two different sites in Colorado—its rural mountain region, a relatively recent immigrant “destination,” and urban Denver, a longstanding immigrant “gateway.”

In terms of intellectual merit, we learned that local-level policies and the local sociopolitical context greatly shaped Latino immigrants’ willingness to seek health care, with dramatically different outcomes for immigrants living in Colorado’s rural mountain regions and those in Denver. The more recent settlement of immigrants in Colorado’s rural mountain regions led to fewer immigrant advocacy organizations, a health care safety net less-well-prepared to serve Spanish-speaking immigrants, and greater obstacles to immigrants’ accessing and paying for care. Meanwhile, in Denver, a “sanctuary city,” a strong immigrant rights movement and active immigrant advocacy organizations made the region immigrant-friendly, while a health care safety net that had long served immigrants established policies more conducive to their health care access.

In terms of broader impacts on society, we each engaged in myriad forms of advocacy and activism to facilitate Latino immigrants’ health care access, health, and wellbeing in each location and in the state at large. In Fall 2021 and Spring 2022, the Co-PIs worked alongside immigrant and health advocacy agencies— such as the Colorado Immigrant Rights Coalition, the Colorado Consumer Health Initiative, and the Colorado Community Health Network—to support legislation to expand access to state Medicaid for undocumented immigrants and to ensure low-income residents’ access to hospital discounts. The Co-PIs shared their research results with these organizations and submitted testimony to the Colorado Department of Health and the Environment in support of these bills, both of which passed. In addition, the Co-PIs each volunteered with local vaccine clinics conducting outreach to the immigrant population in the three counties studied. This project has had important outcomes in terms of helping improve immigrants’ health care access at both the state and local levels.

In Colorado’s rural mountain region—an area long infamous for having some of the highest health care costs in the nation--PI Horton documented the many barriers Latino immigrants faced to obtaining financial assistance with their hospital bills. She shared her participants’ narratives about facing obstacles to receiving hospital financial assistance and to Emergency Medicaid with the Colorado Health Care Policy and Financing Department, which helped the state decide to modify its Emergency Medicaid policies to allow prospective rather than retroactive applications and to extend the eligibility period to a year. She also shared her participants’ frustrations about the care provided by the local community clinic with the clinic directors, and worked with a local nonprofit to conduct outreach to immigrant families about new policies expanding access to health care to mixed-status families in the state. In Denver, PI Duncan actively participated in an immigrant rights organization’s mobilizations to protect immigrant families, and assisted the local support group in which several of her participants participated. During the COVID-19 pandemic, undocumented Latino immigrants in both locations found themselves routinely exposed to the virus in their jobs as “essential workers” and yet excluded not only from unemployment benefits but also from the stimulus. To assist their participants with their everyday needs for economic support and health care, both PIs engaged in multiple forms of “bureaucratic accompaniment” (Horton, forthcoming; Yarris and Duncan, forthcoming) with their participants, attempting to use their privilege as a shield, helping them navigate rental assistance funds, find legal assistance, and locate vaccines and specialty care.
